14. It is true, chestnut is nothing to scorn,
one can put them in the work where one pleases,
in the foreground, to appear with force,
or elsewhere: but I say, to pay attention to
the glossiness, or the glistening of the coat,
as we see making an appearance in Sunshine;
so also in the black. But to receive praise,
be mindful of the flickering hair on the flanks.
left-middleOn glossiness, and on letting the hairs stand up.

15. Study different breeds, such as Horses of Spain,
with their elegant outlines, and then those of Turkey, Barbary
and Naples, or those from the Campagne,
and also, how the Chestnut’s coat is sometimes brown
and sometimes seemingly streaked with honey.
It is difficult to explain
how Nature is so inclined here
to ply her remarkable variety.

16. Beautiful Dapple-gray color, which may not dissemble,
where the hide gleams as if full of scales,
is a joy to see. Then Nature will deceive us
(so it seems), so that one could believe it is
a white coat covered with flies.
There is much more in this regard, but we must know
to paint the Horses’ mouths and noses
in their proper colors, as well as tails and manes.

17. Sometimes the bay has four white feet
and a star will adorn its forehead.
We should also study the Pose,
as in human figures; they walk, stand,
jump, and turn with pure balanced grace.
Study too the white foam, with which
They sow the field, and already showing
signs of running as if in flight.

18. Once, as Valerius Maxiumus has written,
a famous Painter who had made a Horse,
a Horse, wondrously fine, from exhausting work.
And when he wished, among other things,
to affirm his Art, making that foam
that came floating from the mouth,
this artful laborer devoted long
and fruitless time and effort on it.

19. He was unable to complete his artful work,
then, realizing that he tried, suffering,
such small, insignificant and unworthy things,
he was seized with regret.
